tasks: Create a simple wireframe of a login screen using the 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design (nngroup.com) as reference. Focus on following at least 3 heuristics.
Write down 5 common UX mistakes and how to avoid them, referencing Occam's Razor (lawsofux.com).
Sketch out a rough prototype of a product feature using the Aesthetic-Usability Effect (lawsofux.com) as inspiration.
Conduct a self-assessment of your current UX skills, rating yourself on a scale of 1-5 for each of the 10 Usability Heuristics. Identify areas for improvement and create a plan to address them.
Create a mind map or diagram illustrating how Miller’s Law (lawsofux.com) applies to your design process.
Redesign a simple product feature using the 8-point grid system, focusing on balance and harmony.
Research and document 5 common user research methods, including their strengths and weaknesses. Create a pros-and-cons list for each method.
Create a persona using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework, focusing on understanding user needs and motivations.
Conduct a usability test of your own design work, identifying at least 3 areas for improvement.
Develop a comprehensive UX strategy document outlining your approach to designing user-centered products. Include at least 3 key principles and 2 case studies.
Create a visual design system using the 8-point grid system, including typography, color palette, and iconography.
Design a product feature that incorporates all of the skills you've learned throughout this 4-week journey.

resources.readup: As an Explorer UX designer, you have the power to uncover new insights and create seamless experiences for users. By focusing on user research, visual design, and collaboration, you can drive product innovation and shape the future of digital products.

resources.title: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design
resources.description: 7 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design ================================================= Jakob Nielsen ![](https://media.nngroup.com/medi...

topics.name: Understanding Hick's Law and its Impact on UX Design
topics.summary: Applying Hick's Law to design intuitive navigation and minimize cognitive load.
practice_points: Create a wireframe of a website with 5-7 main navigation options, labeling each option with its corresponding response time (e.g., 'Clicking on this option takes approximately 200ms').
Conduct an A/B test to compare the performance of two different navigation systems with varying levels of complexity.
Analyze 3 existing websites and identify instances where Hick's Law is applied, documenting the design decisions behind each instance.

topics.name: Practicing UI Craft through Aesthetic-Usability Effect
topics.summary: Designing visually appealing and usable interfaces that balance aesthetics with functionality.
practice_points: Create a mood board for a hypothetical product, incorporating 3-5 color palettes and typography styles to evoke the desired emotional response.
Develop a consistent visual design language for a fictional company, including logos, icons, and button styles.
Design 2-3 wireframes of a product with varying levels of visual complexity (e.g., simple vs. detailed), evaluating which one is more usable.

topics.name: Applying Occam's Razor to Streamline UX Decision-Making
topics.summary: Using Occam's Razor to simplify complex design decisions and prioritize the most effective solutions.
practice_points: Create a decision tree for a hypothetical product feature, evaluating 5-7 possible solutions and selecting the simplest one.
Analyze 3 existing products or services that have successfully applied Occam's Razor, documenting the design decisions behind each instance.
Develop a set of guiding principles for UX design that incorporate Occam's Razor, providing clear criteria for designers to evaluate complex problems.

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating the foundation of a solid user experience.
insights.detailed: A score of 0 suggests that the UX fundamentals are lacking, resulting in poor navigation, unclear information architecture, and inadequate accessibility. A higher score indicates a stronger understanding of user needs, intuitive design, and effective problem-solving.
actionable: Conduct a heuristic evaluation to identify usability issues and provide recommendations for improvement
Research industry best practices for UX design and incorporate them into the Explorer design process
Create user personas and user journeys to inform design decisions and ensure empathy in the design process

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating the visual appeal and effectiveness of the UI.
insights.detailed: A score of 8 suggests that the UI craft and visual design are strong, resulting in a visually appealing and engaging experience. However, a lower score may indicate a lack of consistency, poor color choices, or inadequate typography.
actionable: Develop a consistent visual language for the Explorer, including typography, color palette, and imagery
Create a style guide to ensure design consistency across all Explorer features and interactions
Conduct user testing to validate design decisions and gather feedback on visual elements

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating the effectiveness of research methods in understanding user needs.
insights.detailed: A score of 0 suggests that user research is lacking, resulting in a design that may not meet user needs. A higher score indicates a thorough understanding of user needs, behaviors, and motivations.
actionable: Conduct user interviews or surveys to gather feedback on the Explorer's usability and effectiveness
Analyze user data and behavior patterns to inform design decisions and identify areas for improvement
Create user personas and user journeys to provide a framework for understanding user needs

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating the alignment of the design with business goals and objectives.
insights.detailed: A score of 0 suggests that product thinking is lacking, resulting in a design that may not meet business needs. A higher score indicates a thorough understanding of business goals, target audience, and market trends.
actionable: Develop a product roadmap to align the Explorer with business objectives and strategic priorities
Conduct competitor analysis to identify market gaps and opportunities for differentiation
Create a business case for the Explorer, including revenue projections and customer acquisition costs

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating the effectiveness of collaboration and communication among team members.
insights.detailed: A score of 0 suggests that collaboration and communication are lacking, resulting in a design that may not meet user needs. A higher score indicates effective collaboration, clear communication, and a shared understanding of design goals and objectives.
actionable: Establish regular design reviews and feedback sessions to ensure alignment among team members
Create a collaborative design process, including shared documents and tools for real-time feedback
